title: Monte Carlo Localization with Cozmo Robot
overlay: Monte Carlo Localization with Cozmo Robot using Python
description_html: In my Monte Carlo Localization (particle filter localization) project with Cozmo Robot, I worked as a team with my partner, implementing a probabilistic algorithm using Python to enable the robot to determine its position within a given environment/arena. The algorithm uses a set of particles to represent possible positions of the robot. Each particle is weighted based on sensor measurements compared to a pre-defined map, allowing the robot to estimate its position with increasing accuracy over time. Main elements of the implementation included sensor data integration, particle weight calculation, resampling techniques, and efficient handling of localization updates to ensure real-time performance.

title: Sokoban Game using C++
description_html: Sokoban Game is a classic puzzle video game in which the player pushes boxes or crates within a warehouse setting, trying to get them to designated storage locations. I implemented this using C++ which included logic for player movements, box interactions, and collision detection, and also making use of SFML for rendering graphics. The Sokoban class manages the game state, player position, and level data, while methods like movePlayer and isWon handle game mechanics and victory conditions. The game employs C++ standard libraries and smart pointers for efficient data management and memory use.

title: Checkers Game using C++
description_html: Checkers is a game of two players played on a board. Each player in this game tries to eliminate all pieces belonging to his or her enemy and prevent those pieces from moving at all by utilizing their own pieces. I implemented this game using C++ that can be played in a terminal with the necessary SFML and C++ libraries. I utilized object-oriented programming principles to manage game states, validate moves, and handle the promotion of pieces to kings. The game supports a graphical user interface using the SFML library, enhancing the user experience with interactive visuals and gameplay mechanics.

title: Personal Portfolio Website
description_html: I designed and developed my Personal Portfolio Website as a full-stack web application to showcase my projects, technical skills, and academic background. The frontend is built using React, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, with an emphasis on responsive design, smooth animations, and an intuitive user interface. The backend is implemented as a RESTful API using Node.js and Express, providing functionality for the contact form by securely handling user input and sending emails via a third-party email service. The frontend is deployed on GitHub Pages, while the backend is deployed on Render, demonstrating end-to-end deployment, environment configuration, and clientâ€“server integration.

title: Interactive Multiplication Table Generator
description_html: I designed an Interactive Multiplication Table Generator using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to provide a dynamic and user-friendly experience. This tool allows users to input a range of numbers to generate a multiplication table dynamically, updating in real-time as inputs are modified. The user interface is designed with simplicity and responsiveness in mind, ensuring that the multiplication tables are easy to read and interact with on various devices.

title: Scrabble Game using JavaScript and jQeury
description_html: This one-line version of the Scrabble game is a streamlined implementation of the classic word game. This version focuses on delivering the core gameplay experience in a concise format, allowing players to form words from a given set of letters to score points based on the value of each letter. The game features a word validation system, a scoring mechanism, and a user-friendly interface for easy interaction. I designed this using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and jQuery, combining these technologies to create a responsive and interactive web application. HTML structures the content, CSS provides the styling, JavaScript handles the game logic, and jQuery simplifies DOM manipulation and enhances the user experience.

title: Web Application Vulnerability Scanner
overlay: Web App Vulnerability Scanner using Python & Flask
description_html: In my Web Application Vulnerability Scanner project, I coordinated a three-person team and helped build a modular security testing web app using Python and Flask (deployed on Render). The tool accepts a target URL and runs a set of automated checks to identify common web security issues, including SQL Injection (SQLi), Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) (reflected, stored, and DOM indicators), security headers and related information leakage, cookie security attributes, SSL/TLS configuration checks (including a Heartbleed test when applicable), and network findings such as open ports and HTTP method exposure. The scan controller runs these modules concurrently using multithreading, and users can choose between a basic or deep scan (with deeper network testing such as directory traversal attempts). Results are displayed in a clean web interface and can be exported as a downloadable PDF report with findings organized by category and paired with remediation guidance.

title: Wearable Data for Recovery and Stress Monitoring
description_html: In the Wearable Data for Recovery and Stress Monitoring project, we worked with the LifeSnaps Fitbit dataset by merging wearable activity data with stress and affect survey scores. Performed data preprocessing including handling missing values, normalization, and feature selection to prepare time-series inputs for modeling. To analyze stress patterns over time, we implemented a Transformer-based model (from scratch using numpy) for temporal stress classification and a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) to capture latent stress and recovery state transitions, allowing comparison between deep learning and probabilistic sequence modeling approaches.
